00018 /** \defgroup transform Other Domain Transform Operations
00019  * \par
00020  * Hough, Distance.
00021  *
00022  * See \ref im_process_glo.h
00023  * \ingroup process */
00024 
00025 /** Hough Lines Transform. \n
00026  * It will detect white lines in a black background. So the source image must be a IM_BINARY image 
00027  * with the white lines of interest enhanced. The better the threshold with the white lines the better 
00028  * the line detection. \n
00029  * The destiny image must have IM_GRAY, IM_INT, hg_width=180, hg_height=2*rmax+1, 
00030  * where rmax is the image diagonal/2 (rmax = srqrt(width*width + height*height)). \n
00031  * The hough transform defines  "cos(theta) * X  + sin(theta) * Y = rho" and the parameters are in the interval: \n
00032  * theta = "0 .. 179", rho = "-hg_height/2 .. hg_height/2" .\n
00033  * Where rho is the perpendicular distance from the center of the image and theta the angle with the normal.
00034  * So do not confuse theta with the line angle, they are perpendicular. \n
00035  * Returns zero if the counter aborted. \n
00036  * Inspired from ideas in XITE, Copyright 1991, Blab, UiO \n
00037  * http://www.ifi.uio.no/~blab/Software/Xite/  \n
00038  * Not using OpenMP when enabled.
00039  *
00040  * \verbatim im.ProcessHoughLines(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00041  * \verbatim im.ProcessHoughLinesNew(image: imImage) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00042  * \ingroup transform */
00043 int imProcessHoughLines(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image);
00044 
00045 /** Draw detected hough lines. \n
00046  * The source and destiny images can be IM_MAP, IM_GRAY or IM_RGB, with data type IM_BYTE. \n
00047  * Can be done in-place. \n
00048  * If the hough transform is not NULL, then the hough points are filtered to include only lines
00049  * that are significally different from each other. \n
00050  * The hough image is the hough transform image, but it is optional and can be NULL. 
00051  * If not NULL then it will be used to filter lines that are very similar. \n
00052  * The hough points image is a hough transform image that was thresholded to a IM_BINARY image, 
00053  * usually using a Local Max threshold operation (see \ref imProcessLocalMaxThreshold). Again the better the threshold the better the results. \n
00054  * The detected lines will be drawn using a red color.
00055  * If the destiny image is IM_GRAY, it will be changed to IM_MAP. \n
00056  * If the destiny image is IM_RGB, then only the red plane will be changed.
00057  * Returns the number of detected lines. \n
00058  * Not using OpenMP when enabled.
00059  *
00060  * \verbatim im.ProcessHoughLinesDraw(src_image: imImage, hough: imImage, hough_points: imImage, dst_image: imImage) -> lines: number [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00061  * \verbatim im.ProcessHoughLinesDrawNew(image: imImage, hough: imImage, hough_points: imImage) -> lines: number, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00062  * \ingroup transform */
00063 int imProcessHoughLinesDraw(const imImage* src_image, const imImage* hough, const imImage* hough_points, imImage* dst_image);
00064 
00065 /** Calculates the Cross Correlation in the frequency domain. \n 
00066  * CrossCorr(a,b) = IFFT(Conj(FFT(a))*FFT(b)) \n
00067  * Images must be of the same size and only destiny image must be of type complex.
00068  *
00069  * \verbatim im.ProcessCrossCorrelation(src_image1: imImage, src_image2: imImage, dst_image: imImage) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00070  * \verbatim im.ProcessCrossCorrelationNew(image1: imImage, image2: imImage) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00071  * \ingroup transform */
00072 void imProcessCrossCorrelation(const imImage* src_image1, const imImage* src_image2, imImage* dst_image);
00073 
00074 /** Calculates the Auto Correlation in the frequency domain. \n 
00075  * Uses the cross correlation.
00076  * Images must be of the same size and only destiny image must be of type complex.
00077  *
00078  * \verbatim im.ProcessAutoCorrelation(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00079  * \verbatim im.ProcessAutoCorrelationNew(image: imImage) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00080  * \ingroup transform */
00081 void imProcessAutoCorrelation(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image);
00082 
00083 /** Calculates the Distance Transform of a binary image 
00084  * using an aproximation of the euclidian distance.\n
00085  * Each white pixel in the binary image is
00086  * assigned a value equal to its distance from the nearest
00087  * black pixel. \n
00088  * Uses a two-pass algorithm incrementally calculating the distance. \n
00089  * Source image must be IM_BINARY, destiny must be IM_FLOAT.
00090  *
00091  * \verbatim im.ProcessDistanceTransform(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00092  * \verbatim im.ProcessDistanceTransformNew(image: imImage) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00093  * \ingroup transform */
00094 void imProcessDistanceTransform(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image);
00095 
00096 /** Marks all the regional maximum of the distance transform. \n
00097  * source is IMGRAY/IM_FLOAT destiny in IM_BINARY. \n
00098  * We consider maximum all connected pixel values that have smaller pixel values around it.
00099  *
00100  * \verbatim im.ProcessRegionalMaximum(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00101  * \verbatim im.ProcessRegionalMaximumNew(image: imImage) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00102  * \ingroup transform */
00103 void imProcessRegionalMaximum(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image);
00104 
00105 
00106 
00107 /** \defgroup fourier Fourier Transform Operations
00108  * \par
00109  * All Fourier transforms use FFTW library. \n
00110  * The pre-compiled binaries for FFTW version 2.1.5 includes all the necessary files.
00111  * The pre-compiled binaries for FFTW version 3.x depends on an external library, not provided.
00112  * To build the code that uses FFTW version 3 you must define USE_FFTW3.
00113  * \par
00114  * FFTW Copyright Matteo Frigo, Steven G. Johnson and the MIT. \n
00115  * http://www.fftw.org                                         \n
00116  * See "fftw.h"
00117  * \par
00118  * Must link with "im_fftw" library. \n
00119  * \par
00120  * IMPORTANT: The FFTW lib has a GPL license. The license of the "im_fftw" library is automatically the GPL.
00121  * So you cannot use it for commercial applications without contacting the authors. 
00122  * \par
00123  * See \ref im_process_glo.h
00124  * \ingroup process */
00125 
00126 /** Forward FFT. \n
00127  * The result has its lowest frequency at the center of the image. \n
00128  * This is an unnormalized fft. \n
00129  * Images must be of the same size. Destiny image must be of type complex.
00130  *
00131  * \verbatim im.ProcessFFT(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00132  * \verbatim im.ProcessFFTNew(image: imImage) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00133  * \ingroup fourier */
00134 void imProcessFFT(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image);
00135 
00136 /** Inverse FFT. \n
00137  * The image has its lowest frequency restored to the origin before the transform. \n
00138  * The result is normalized by (width*height). \n
00139  * Images must be of the same size and both must be of type complex.
00140  *
00141  * \verbatim im.ProcessIFFT(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00142  * \verbatim im.ProcessIFFTNew(image: imImage) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00143  * \ingroup fourier */
00144 void imProcessIFFT(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image);
00145 
00146 /** Raw in-place FFT (forward or inverse). \n
00147  * The lowest frequency can be centered after forward, or
00148  * can be restored to the origin before inverse. \n
00149  * The result can be normalized after the transform by sqrt(w*h) [1] or by (w*h) [2], 
00150  * or left unnormalized [0]. \n
00151  * Images must be of the same size and both must be of type complex.
00152  *
00153  * \verbatim im.ProcessFFTraw(image: imImage, inverse: number, center: number, normalize: number) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00154  * \ingroup fourier */
00155 void imProcessFFTraw(imImage* image, int inverse, int center, int normalize);
00156 
00157 /** Auxiliary function for the raw FFT. \n 
00158  * This is the function used internally to change the lowest frequency position in the image. \n
00159  * If the image size has even dimensions the flag "center2origin" is useless. But if it is odd, 
00160  * you must specify if its from center to origin (usually used before inverse) or
00161  * from origin to center (usually used after forward). \n
00162  * Notice that this function is used for images in the the frequency domain. \n
00163  * Image type must be complex.
00164  *
00165  * \verbatim im.ProcessSwapQuadrants(image: imImage, center2origin: number) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00166  * \ingroup fourier */
00167 void imProcessSwapQuadrants(imImage* image, int center2origin);
00168

00171 /** \defgroup openmp OpenMP Utilities
00172  * \par
00173  * Used inside im_process_omp only. But also exported to Lua.
00174  * These functions do not use OpenMP, 
00175  * they are used when OpenMP is enabled in im_process.
00176  * See \ref im_util.h
00177  * \ingroup process */
00178 
00179 /** Sets the minimum number of interations to split into threads. \n
00180  * Default value is 250000, or an image with 500x500. \n
00181  * Returns the previous value.
00182  *
00183  * \verbatim im.ProcessOpenMPSetMinCount(min_count: number) -> old_min_count: number [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00184  * \ingroup openmp */
00185 int imProcessOpenMPSetMinCount(int min_count);
00186 
00187 /** Sets the number of threads. \n
00188  * Does nothing if OpenMP is not enabled. \n
00189  * Returns the previous value.
00190  *
00191  * \verbatim im.ProcessOpenMPSetNumThreads(min_count: number) -> old_min_count: number [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00192  * \ingroup openmp */
00193 int imProcessOpenMPSetNumThreads(int count);
